thread.title: Fears Kingston Flyer will be taken off heritage register
thread.title_full: Fears Kingston Flyer will be taken off heritage register

author: Che Baker
title: Fears Kingston Flyer will be taken off heritage register
text:
Fears Kingston Flyer will be taken off heritage register CHE BAKER Last updated 16:28, September 20 2015 Barry Harcourt 
The Kingston Flyer in action. 
Kingston Flyer advocate Karl Barkley says those who want to keep the steam train in the area have to save it from being removed from a heritage list. 
Barkley said the Queenstown Lakes District Council have removed the two steam locomotives and seven wooden carriages from the Heritage Register in the 2015 District Plan. 
If the proposal went ahead, any new purchaser could remove the steam train set from Kingston, ending its 43 years history in the area. Supplied 
The Kingston Flyer sits unused in Kingston. 
"It's the last chance. If it's up for grabs it will be removed." 
The Kingston Flyer sits unused in Kingston. 
Barkley urged supporters to contact the council before October 24, to have the rolling stock added back onto the heritage register, when submissions on the district plan closed. 
"Stop the stupidity of taking it off the heritage register," Barkley said. 
The council should buy it, set it aside and find investors, he said. 
"There are people out there interested but we've got to get that ownership," he said. 
He believed an investment of $5 million or more would be needed to get it running again.
